newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Swedish bond yields end marginally lower, off lows.
newsitem.headline: Swedish bond yields end marginally lower, off lows.

text.p: Swedish bond yields ended marginally lower on Wednesday, pushed off morning and midday lows by weaker international markets following a stronger than expected U.S. March trade deficit.
The U.S. March trade deficit shrunk to $8.51 billion while analysts had expected $10.3 billion.
"The U.S., Germany and Italy have performed poorly," a trader said. "There has been a downward correction in Europe."
The fact that the spread between Swedish and German long yields has narrowed sharply recently also called for a correction, he added.
"It's a very nervous market," he said.

Yields opened lower after a Tuesday five-party agreement to strengthen the Riksbank's position that some dealers saw paving the way for a link to Europe's economic and monetary union (EMU). But when foreign markets softened Swedish yields came off earlier lows.
Six-month T-bill rates fell one basis point to 4.19 percent and the ten-year bond yield slid one basis point to 6.94 percent. The crown firmed to 4.4550 against the mark from 4.4740 late on Tuesday.
